member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.AuthenticationPlugin
member.summary: The base class for custom, external authentication plug-in for the Captiva REST service.

remarks.para: Custom authentication is typically used if the remote-user credentials are authenticated by a non-Windows system such as CAS. The implementation must process the credentials, if any, and the extra authentication info and return the appropriate Captiva Capture user and roles. The roles are then used by the REST service for authentication with the Captiva Capture server.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.AuthenticationPlugin.AuthenticateAndMapToInputAccelRole(System.String,System.Char[],System.Char[])
member.summary: Authenticates a user and maps the user to one or more Captiva Capture roles.
member.param: The user name or an empty string if none was supplied.
The clear text password as an array or an empty array if none was supplied.
Any additional authentication information, such as a ticket from an external authentication server such as CAS, or an empty string if none was supplied.
member.returns: An array of Captiva role names for the user.

remarks.para: This method must be implemented by custom plug-ins.
If the authentication fails for the specified user, the method must throw an exception.

The , , and are the values passed as clear text in the JSON body of the POST /session login request. The is cleared after the method is complete. Plug-in authors may also explicitly clear the and values.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.AuthenticationPlugin.CustomParameter
member.summary: Gets or sets a custom value used by the plug-in.

remarks.para: The value is initialized to the custom parameter defined as part of the Captiva REST Service configuration, if any. For example, if CAS is used as the authentication server, this string may contain the CAS server.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule
member.summary: The base class for custom code.

remarks.para:
A custom code assembly must contain a class that inherits from this base class. Add the code that will perform custom actions to the
method of your subclass.
remarks.note:
You custom subclass must also contain a default constructor. The example in
demonstrates how to create a default constructor.

example.para: The following is a Visual Basic class that implements custom behaviors:
example.code:
Public Class MyCustomModule Inherits CustomCodeModule
Public Sub New() End Sub
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext) ' CUSTOM ACTIONS GO HERE End Sub
Public Overrides Sub StartModule(ByVal startInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo) End Sub
End Class
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.StartModule(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.ICodeModuleStartInfo)
member.summary: Runs just before the first task is processed in production mode.
member.param: Information about the module.

remarks.para: For each process, this method runs only once during each .NET Code Module session, as soon as the module receives its first task for a batch based on that process. It runs multiple times during a module session if the module receives tasks based on different processes. It is followed immediately by .
You must override this method in your custom subclass, creating your own implementation. If you do not want to perform any custom actions when the module starts, simply leave the function body empty.
The parameter provides properties and methods that affect the running instance of the module.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code creates a class-level variable (moduleStartInfo) to hold the module information. The StartModule method assigns the module data to the class variable, then the method uses it to set a status bar message.
example.code:
Public Class MyCustomModule Inherits CustomCodeModule
Dim moduleStartInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo
Public Sub New() End Sub
Public Overrides Sub StartModule(ByVal startInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo) moduleStartInfo = startInfo End Sub
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext) moduleStartInfo.ShowStatusMessage("Processing task...") End Sub
End Class
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.StopModule
member.summary: Runs just before the .NET Code Module exits production mode.

remarks.para: You may override this method in your custom subclass. If you do not, no custom actions will run when the module exits.
remarks.note: When the .NET Code Module is running in application mode, this method runs just after the module window is closed.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.ExecuteTask(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IClientTask,Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchContext)
member.summary: Performs task processing.

remarks.para: Add your custom task processing code to this method. It will be called when the batch is opened by the module.
The parameters provide access to the batch data as well as general information about the task.
remarks.note:
A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. The parameters to this method provide access to batch nodes in the context of the .NET Code Module step that is running the custom code. To retrieve node values for other steps, use the
method to change the context of the node.
remarks.para:
Before the ExecuteTask method returns, you must call either
to indicate successful completion, or
to mark the task as failed. If you do not call either method, the module throws an exception and returns code IA_ERR_RETRYSOME (-6113) to the workflow server.

member.param: Task information.
The entire batch. The parameter provides access to all batch nodes, regardless of the level at which the task was received. This parameter is null if RequiresAccessToCompleteBatch is false.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.SetupCodeModule(System.Windows.Forms.Control,Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IValueAccessor)
member.summary: Performs custom module setup tasks.
member.param: The module window. If you display a custom window, you should specify this module window as its owner.
Provides access to the configuration values for the workflow step. These are the step values defined generally for the batch or process. To set node-specific values, use .
member.returns: True if the configuration settings should be saved. False if any configuration changes are to be discarded.

remarks.para: This method applies only when the module is run in setup mode. If the method exists, a custom setup option is available in the module. When an administrator chooses to run the custom setup, this method executes.

You can display a user interface that enables the administrator to change step configuration options. Choose step configuration options to expose by accessing the parameter. Return a Boolean value indicating whether or not the configuration value changes should be saved.
remarks.note: If the entire step configuration is canceled, custom changes to the configuration values are discarded regardless of what value this method returns.
remarks.para: If you do not override this method in your custom subclass, the custom setup option is not available when the .NET Code Module step is configured with this assembly.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.SetupCodeModule(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IValueAccessor)
member.summary: Performs custom module setup tasks.
member.param: Provides access to the configuration values for the workflow step. These are the step values defined generally for the batch or process. To set node-specific values, use .
member.returns: True if the configuration settings should be saved. False if any configuration changes are to be discarded.

remarks.para: This method applies only when the module is run in setup mode. If the method exists, a custom setup option is available in the module. When an administrator chooses to run the custom setup, this method executes.

You can display a user interface that enables the administrator to change step configuration options. Choose step configuration options to expose by accessing the parameter. Return a Boolean value indicating whether or not the configuration value changes should be saved.
remarks.note: If the entire step configuration is canceled, custom changes to the configuration values are discarded regardless of what value this method returns.
remarks.para: If you do not override this method in your custom subclass, the custom setup option is not available when the .NET Code Module step is configured with this assembly.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.CanProcessTasksInParallel
member.summary: Indicates whether the custom code assembly is capable of processing multiple tasks in parallel.

remarks.para:
You can set this property to true if your custom code is capable of accepting multiple tasks at the same time--in other words, if multiple instances of the
method can be run simultaneously without causing a conflict. This is typically true if your custom task processing does not read and write global data that affects more than one task.
Setting this property to true tells the system that it is safe to send tasks in parallel. However, it does not guarantee that tasks will always be sent in parallel.
The default value for this property is false, meaning that a new task is sent to the module only when processing for the previous task is complete.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.RequiresAccessToCompleteBatch
member.summary: If true then the code requires access to complete batch irrespective of task level. The IBatchContext parameter in ExecuteTask() is non null.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.CustomCodeModule.IsSetupUiWpf
member.summary: Indicates whether module setup UI is WPF based UI.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchContext
member.summary: A batch.

remarks.para: This interface provides access to an entire batch, which includes batch data and some associated system metadata.

To access the nodes of the batch tree, use the
method.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchContext.GetRoot(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the batch root node in the context of a specific batch step.

remarks.para:
A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. The
property provides access to data that varies depending on the step context.

You can access the batch data from any module step, regardless of which module it is. However, you must know the name of the step as defined in the CaptureFlow process upon which the batch is based. An exception is thrown if the parameter does not match the name of any step in the batch.

member.param: The name of the batch step for which you want the root node. This name is case-insensitive ("SCAN" is the same as "Scan").
member.returns: The batch root node, in the context of the requested step.

example.para: The following code retrieves the batch root node in the context of the step named "InputScanStep":
example.code: batchContext.GetRoot("InputScanStep")

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchContext.GetStepNode(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode,System.String)
member.summary: Changes the step context for a batch node.

remarks.para:
A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. The
property provides access to data that varies depending on the step context.

The GetStepNode method takes a batch node as a parameter, and returns the same batch node with the step context changed to the requested step. You must know the name of the step as defined in the CaptureFlow process upon which the batch is based. An exception is thrown if the parameter does not match the name of any step in the batch.
The returned batch node enables unconditional browsing and is not restricted to the same subtree as the parameter.

member.param: The batch node for which you want to change the step context.
The name of the batch step to change the context to. This name is case-insensitive ("SCAN" is the same as "Scan").
member.returns: The batch node equivalent to , with the step context changed to .

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode
member.summary: A batch node from a workflow step.

remarks.para: This interface provides access to a specific batch node. You can use this interface to access node data, and to perform certain operations on the structure of the batch tree.
A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. Some node properties, such as , provide access to data that is dependent upon the step context.

Every node above level 0 can contain other nodes. You can access nodes at lower levels by using the
and
methods.

Depending on the context, you might be able to access batch nodes at higher levels by using the
and
properties and the
method. However, custom code access is restricted to the module context of the node. Modules other than the .NET Code Module are can access only the portion of the batch explicitly passed as part of the task. Unless the task is passed at level 7 to the context step, your custom code cannot directly access the entire batch through this interface. However, you can use the
method to retrieve the node in an unrestricted context.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.EnsureNodeValues(System.Int32,System.String[])
member.summary: Ensures that values are available for all the related nodes at the given level for the given value names. This a bulk operation and in cases where client is running out of process then all values are bulked and sent from server improving performance.
member.param: If less than current node level then values are ensured for all descendents at that level. If same or greater then values are ensured for that node.
Value names for the given node level.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.GetAncestorNodeIdAbsolutePath
member.summary: Returns the sequence of node IDs for the context node's ancestors.

remarks.para: An ancestor is a node that contains the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct container (parent node), the parent's container, and so forth up to the root node of the batch.

When you call this method, you get an array of node IDs of all of the ancestors of the context node. The first entry is the ID of the node at the highest accessible level. The last entry is immediate parent's node ID.
If the context node has no accessible parent nodes, the resulting array is empty.
remarks.note: In some contexts, you cannot access nodes higher than the task node.

member.returns: An array of ancestor node IDs, starting from the top of the tree.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.GetAncestor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an ancestor of the context node.

remarks.para:
An ancestor is a node that contains the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct container (parent node), the parent's container, and so forth up to the root node of the batch. Calling GetAncestor with a level one higher than the context node's level is equivalent to retrieving the
property.
remarks.note: In some contexts, you cannot access nodes higher than the task node.

member.param: The level of the ancestor node to retrieve.
member.returns: The requested ancestor node.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.GetChildren
member.summary: Returns the direct children of the context node.

remarks.para:
When you call this method, you get an array of
objects in the order in which they occur.

Calling GetChildren is equivalent to calling the
method with a level one lower than the context node's level.
If the context node has no child nodes, the resulting array is empty.

member.returns: An array of child nodes.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.GetDescendantNodes(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the descendents of the context node at a specified node level.

remarks.para:
A descendant is a node contained inside the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct child, the child's child, and so forth down to the level 0 (page) nodes. Calling GetDescendantNodes with a level one lower than the context node's level is equivalent to calling the
method.

When you call this method, you get an array of
objects in the order in which they occur.
If the context node has no descendant nodes at the requested level, the resulting array is empty.

member.param: The level at which to retrieve descendant nodes.
member.returns: An array of descendant nodes at the specified level.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.AddNewChild(System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a new child node.

remarks.para:
This method adds a child node to the context node on which the method is run. The child node is inserted just before the node with the ID specified as the parameter. You can retrieve the unique ID of any existing batch node using the
property.
The parameter takes the following special values:

item.description: Inserts the node at the beginning of the child collection (before all other nodes).
Inserts the node at the end of the child collection (after all other nodes).

remarks.note: If you specify a value that is neither the ID of a child node nor one of the special values, the node is inserted at the end of the child collection.
remarks.para: You can use this method on any node at level 1 or above. Attempting to add a new child to a level 0 (page) node results in an exception.

member.param: The ID of the node before which the new node should be inserted (or -1 to insert at the end).
member.returns: The new node that has been added.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.RemoveDescendantById(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes a descendant node.

remarks.para: A descendant is a node contained inside the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct child, the child's child, and so forth down to the level 0 (page) nodes.

Specify the node to remove according to its ID. You can use the
property to find the ID of a node. If the node specified for removal does not exist or is not a descendent of the context node, no change is made to the node tree.
Removing a node also removes all of its child nodes.

member.param: The ID of the node to remove.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.MoveDescendant(System.Int32,Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves a descendant node to a different position.

remarks.para: A descendant is a node contained inside the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct child, the child's child, and so forth down to the level 0 (page) nodes.

You can use this method to change the sequence of child nodes within a single parent node, or to move a node from one parent to another. However, you cannot move a node to a different level. For example, you can move a page node (level 0) to a different document (level 1), but you cannot move it so that it is contained directly within a folder (level 2).

Specify the node to move according to its ID. It will be inserted just before the node with the ID specified as the parameter. You can use the
property to find the ID of a node. If the node you try to move does not exist or is not a descendent of the context node, no change is made to the node tree.
The parameter takes the following special values:

item.description: Inserts the node at the beginning of the collection (before all other nodes).
Inserts the node at the end of the collection (after all other nodes).

remarks.note: If you specify a value that is neither the ID of a child node nor one of the special values, the node is inserted at the end of the child collection.

member.param: The ID of the node to move.
The new parent node. This can be the same node as the current parent node, or another node at the same level as the current parent node.
The ID of the node before which the new node should be inserted (or -1 to insert at the end). If a node ID is specified, it must be a direct child node of .
member.returns: True if the node was successfully moved; false otherwise.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code moves the first page of document 2 so that it becomes the last page of document 1:
example.code:
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext)
Dim batchRoot As IBatchNode Dim batchFolder As IBatchNode Dim doc1 As IBatchNode Dim doc2 As IBatchNode Dim doc1Page1 As IBatchNode Dim doc2Page1 As IBatchNode
batchRoot = batchContext.GetRoot("Code") batchFolder = batchRoot.GetDescendantNodes(2)(0) doc1 = batchFolder.GetChildren()(0) doc2 = batchFolder.GetChildren()(1) doc1Page1 = doc1.GetChildren()(0) doc2Page1 = doc2.GetChildren()(0)
batchFolder.MoveDescendant(doc2Page1.NodeData.NodeId, doc1, -1)
task.CompleteTask()
End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.SplitParent(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Splits parent node into two nodes.
Parent node is splited by creating new right sibling to parent node. Right sibling nodes of this node and their decendant nodes becomes decendant nodes of newly created parent node's sibling node.
member.param: This node is included in newly created right sibling of parent node if this params true, else it stays with parent node
member.returns: Newly created right sibling to parent node

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.MergeWithSibling
member.summary:
Merge this node with left sibling node.
Descendants of this node becomes decendants of sibling to which this node is merged

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IBatchNode.GetFormattedValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates a string expression using values from the current node context.

remarks.para: The parameter specifies the expression you want to evaluate. It can contain a combination of static text and variables. Each variable name must be enclosed within curly braces ( { } ). To put a curly brace in the expression as a literal character, enclose it within curly braces. For example, {{} outputs {
The following variables are available:

item.description: Evaluates to the node ID as an ordinary decimal number (base 10).
Evaluates to the node ID as a hexadecimal number (base 16). The evaluated expression contains only the hex digits, without any hexadecimal prefix indicator such as &H or 0x

x is a single-digit integer specifying a node level. This expression evaluates to the 1-based index (position) of the node itself or its ancestor node at the specified level, within that target node's parent. For example, @0 on a page node (level 0) evaluates to its position with its containing document (level 1). @1 on the same node evaluates to the document's position within its containing folder (level 2). @7 always evaluates to 1 because the batch root node is the only node at level 7.

x and y are each single-digit integers specifying node levels. This expression evaluates to one of the following:
If x < y, the 1-based index (position) of the node itself or its ancestor node at level x within that target node's ancestor at level y. For example, @02 on a page node (level 0) evaluates to its position among all pages within its containing folder (level 2). @01 on the same node would evaluate to its position with its containing document, which is the same value specified by @0.
If x > y, the number of descendants at level y of the node or its ancestor at level x, where x must be the same as the level of the context node. For example, @20 on a folder node (level 2) evaluates to the total number of pages within the folder.
If x = y, the number 0.

Evaluates to the specified context node value. A value defined for the current .NET Code Module step can be retrieved by its simple names (for example, "SubTreeModified"). A value defined for a different batch step must be prefixed with the appropriate step name (for example, "ScanPlus.SubTreeModified").

Works like @(valuename), except that if the value does not exist on the context node, the ancestors of the context node are checked in ascending order. For example, if the context node is a page (level 0), and the specified value name does not exist, the document (level 1) is checked. If the value does not exist there, the folder (level 2) is checked, and so on to the top of the tree. The
is substituted only if the value is not found on the context node or on any of its ancestor nodes.

member.param: The string expression to evaluate.
The string to substitute for each expression variable that does not exist or is empty.
member.returns: The evaluated string.

example.para: Suppose that a scan operator's user name is "jsmith", the scan workstation's computer name is "Scan1", the ScanPlus module step name in the process is "ScanStep", and there is no value named "Prefix". If "currentNode" is a variable that holds the context node object, then the following string expression resolves to "TheDefaultValue_jsmith_Scan1":
example.code: currentNode.GetFormattedValue("@(Prefix)_@(ScanStep.ScanOperator)_@(ScanStep.ScanMachine)", "TheDefaultValue")
example.para: Suppose the node tree has two documents contained within the same folder. Document 1 has 4 pages, and Document 2 has 5 pages. The context node is Document 2, Page 3.
The following string expressions evaluate to the results shown:

item.description:
3
This is the index of the level 0 node (the page itself) within its parent document.

3
This is the index of the level 0 node (the page itself) within its parent document. (Same as the previous example.)

7
This is the 7th page within the context node's level 2 ancestor (the folder).

2
This is the index of the level 1 node (the document that contains the page) within its parent folder.

with a level one higher than the context node's level.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IBatchNodeData
member.summary: A batch node from a workflow step.

remarks.para: This interface provides access to a specific batch node. You can use this interface to access node data. A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step.

Every node above level 0 can contain other nodes. You can access nodes at lower levels by using the
method.You can access batch nodes at higher levels by using the
method. You can use the
method to retrieve the same node in the context of a different step.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IBatchNodeData.GetStepNode(System.String)
member.summary: Changes the step context for a batch node.

remarks.para: A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. The GetStepNode method returns the same batch node with the step context changed to the requested step. You must know the name of the step as defined in the CaptureFlow process upon which the batch is based. An exception is thrown if the parameter does not match the name of any step in the batch.

member.param: The name of the batch step to change the context to. This name is case-insensitive ("SCAN" is the same as "Scan").
member.returns: The batch node equivalent to the current node, with the step context changed to .

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IBatchNodeData.GetAncestor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an ancestor of the context node.

remarks.para: An ancestor is a node that contains the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct container (parent node), the parent's container, and so forth up to the root node of the batch.

member.param: The level of the ancestor node to retrieve.
member.returns: The requested ancestor node.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IBatchNodeData.GetDescendantNodes(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the descendents of the context node at a specified node level.

remarks.para: A descendant is a node contained inside the context node on which the method is run. This can be the node's direct child, the child's child, and so forth down to the level 0 (page) nodes.

When you call this method, you get an array of
objects in the order in which they occur.
If the context node has no descendant nodes at the requested level, the resulting array is empty.

member.param: The level at which to retrieve descendant nodes.
member.returns: An array of descendant nodes at the specified level.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IUimFieldDataAccessor.SetValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the data value, updating the text shown in UI.

remarks.para: When the field value is set, the new value is formatted and stored as the field text.
Validation rules for the field are never reevaluated when the field value is changed in CaptureFlow scripting, regardless of whether or not the new value is different than the current value.
If has a different data type than the field, the value is converted to the field's data type. If the conversion fails, the field value and text are both set to the default for the field's data type.

member.param: The new field value.

member.summary: Gets the field name.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IUimFieldDataAccessor.Text
member.summary: Gets the text value for the field.

remarks.para: The field text does not necessarily match the field value. If this is a numeric or date/time field and OCR extracts or the user enters a value that cannot be parsed according to the data type, such as entering "ABC" for a numeric field, the text is that from OCR or the user but the underlying value is the default for the field type.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureFlow.IUimFieldDataAccessor.Value
member.summary: Gets the data value for the field.

member.summary: Gets the data value as a double.

remarks.para: If the value cannot be converted an exception is thrown. Booleans are converted to 0 if false and 1 if true. DateTimes are convered to the number of days since midnight, 30 December 1899.

member.summary: Gets the data value as a 32-bit integer (Int32).

remarks.para: If the value cannot be converted an exception is thrown. Booleans are converted to 0 if false and 1 if true. Doubles and decimals are rounded down.

member.summary: Gets the data value as a string.

remarks.para: If the value cannot be converted an exception is thrown. Booleans are converted to "false" or "true".

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IClientTask
member.summary: A client task.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IClientTask.CompleteTask
member.summary: Finishes the task with a successful status.

remarks.para: Task processing must end with a call to either CompleteTask or .
Calling CompleteTask indicates that processing for the current task is complete and successful. The system is free to move the appropriate batch data to the next step of the CaptureFlow process.
remarks.note: Calling this method invalidates the task object. Do not try to access the task after calling this method.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IClientTask.FailTask(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.FailTaskReasonCode,System.Exception)
member.summary: Finishes the task with a failure status.

remarks.para:
Task processing must end with a call to either
or FailTask.

Calling FailTask indicates that processing for the current task did not complete successfully. The task is passed back to the system with a failure code (). The error handling logic in the CaptureFlow process then routes the task according to the error code information.
remarks.note: Calling this method invalidates the task object. Do not try to access the task after calling this method.

member.param: The reason for the error.
The exception that should be used to fail the task.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IClientTask.SaveChanges
member.summary: Commits all changes to batch node data.

remarks.para: The client infrastructure may cache batch node changes in the client side process. These changes are automatically saved when a task is completed and are discarded when a task is failed. This method allows the client module to save changes prior to task completion, guaranteeing that all changes done so far are committed.

The client infrastructure does not always guarantee that all changes are bufferred. In some cases, changes to batch node may commit immediately and such changes are not rolled back if the task fails or is cancelled.

member.summary: Logs an error message to the database.
member.param: The kind of error to log.
The source of the error such as the name of a method.
The error message text.

member.summary: Applies a sequence of filters to an image.

remarks.para: This method can be overridden to optimize how multiple filters are applied to an image. For example, if two consecutive filters can be combined in a single pass over the image that may be more efficient than processing each filter separately. All filters passed to this method are guaranteed to be defined in this assembly.
Filter creators are not required to override this method. The default implementation applies the filters one at a time.

The array of filter configurations in the same order as the filter array.
The input image onto which filters are applied.
A collection of named values returned by the method.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IStageFile
member.summary: A stage file used during task processing.

remarks.para: A stage file is a physical file pointed to by a value of type "File". Stage files are used during batch processing, and the stage files for a batch are automatically deleted from disk after the batch has been completely processed.
From within a process, stage files are referenced through their assigned values rather than directly by file name or location.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IStageFileReader
member.summary: A stage file used during task processing, available only for read operations.

remarks.para: A stage file is a physical file pointed to by a value of type "File". Stage files are used during batch processing, and the stage files for a batch are automatically deleted from disk after the batch has been completely processed.
From within a process, stage files are referenced through their assigned values rather than directly by file name or location.

This interface provides read-only access to a stage file. The
interface provides read/write access.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IStageFileReader.ReadData
member.summary: Reads data from the file to a data stream.

remarks.para: If the stage file is not initialized, an empty stream is returned.

When you have finished read operations, you should close the stream by calling the
method.

member.returns: A data stream with the contents of the file.

member.summary: Reads data from the file to a byte array.

remarks.para: A physical file is created when data is first written to a stage file. If you create a new stage file, it starts out "uninitialized", meaning that no physical file exists. The file is created only when data is first written to the stage file through the stage file object.

Id Integer Batch identifier

Time Stamp String Batch time stamp in server timezone in format "yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss" Where
yyyy -> Year represented by a full four or five digits, depending on the calendar used. MM -> Month as digits with leading zeros for single-digit months. dd -> Day of the month as digits with leading zeros for single-digit days. HH -> Hours with leading zero for single-digit hours; 24-hour clock. mm -> Minutes with leading zero for single-digit minutes. ss -> Seconds with leading zero for single-digit seconds.

Priority String Batch priority

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IModuleStartInfo
member.summary: Interface IModuleStartInfo represents client module start information that is passed once before any task is delivered to the client. Clients use the members to access shared services like trace and shared resources like ParentWindow. All methods are multi thread safe.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.ICodeModuleStartInfo
member.summary: Startup information for the .NET Code Module.

remarks.para: This interface provides access to general information about the running module and its current configuration.

An object of this type is passed to the
method just before the first task is processed.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code shows how to create a class-level variable that provides access to the module start information from any method in the class:
example.code:
Public Class MyCustomModule Inherits CustomCodeModule ' VARIABLE ACCESSIBLE FROM ANYWHERE IN THE CLASS Dim moduleInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo
Public Sub New() End Sub
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext) ' SHOW STATUS MESSAGE moduleInfo.ShowStatusMessage( "Task level is " + task.BatchNode.NodeData.NodeLevel.ToString() ) task.CompleteTask() End Sub
Public Overrides Sub StartModule(ByVal startInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo) ' SET CLASS-LEVEL VARIABLE TO START INFORMATION moduleInfo = startInfo End Sub
End Class
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.ICodeModuleStartInfo.ShowStatusMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Outputs a message to the module processing log.

remarks.para: Use this method to display a timestamped custom message in the module window.
remarks.note: If you call this method with an empty string, it is ignored. It does not display an empty timestamped message.
remarks.para: This method has no effect if the module is running as a service.

member.param: The text of the message to display.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.ICodeModuleStartInfo.Trace(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes a message to the module trace log.

remarks.para: Trace messages are for debug purposes. For trace messages to be output, the module must be started with the -trace command line argument, as in the following example:
"D:\Program Files\InputAccel\Client\binnt\QuickModuleHost.exe" -modulename:Emc.InputAccel.Code -trace:c:\error.log
Trace messages are written only to the file specified on the command line. Trace messages are not sent to the workflow server.

The message you write to the trace log can include variables that are replaced with values from the parameter. Variables are in the format {n}, where n is an integer greater than or equal to 0. Variables are replaced in numerical sequence.
remarks.note: The trace log contains messages written by the module itself, as well as those written by your custom code.

member.param: The message to write to the trace log.
Replacement values for the variables in the parameter. This can be a single value or an array of values. Numbers are converted automatically to strings.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code writes a trace message with information about special folders on the system. Notice that the array items are written in reverse order because the variable {1} occurs before the variable {0} in the message string.
example.code: Public Overrides Sub StartModule(ByVal startInfo As ICodeModuleStartInfo) Dim replacementValues(2) As String replacementValues(0) = startInfo.TempDirectoryPath replacementValues(1) = System.Environment.GetFolderPath(System.Environment.SpecialFolder.MyDocuments) startInfo.Trace("User's document folder: ""{1}"". Current temporary folder: ""{0}"".", replacementValues) End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.ICodeModuleStartInfo.Trace(System.Exception,System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes a message to the module trace log, with exception data.

remarks.para: Trace messages are for debug purposes. For trace messages to be output, the module must be started with the -trace command line argument, as in the following example:
"D:\Program Files\InputAccel\Client\binnt\QuickModuleHost.exe" -modulename:Emc.InputAccel.Code -trace:c:\error.log
Trace messages are written only to the file specified on the command line. Trace messages are not sent to the workflow server.

The message you write to the trace log can include variables that are replaced with values from the parameter. Variables are in the format {n}, where n is an integer greater than or equal to 0. Variables are replaced in numerical sequence. If the same numbered variable is used twice, it is replaced both times by the same runtime value.
remarks.note: The trace log contains messages written by the module itself, as well as those written by your custom code.

member.param: The exception object to add to the trace message.
The message to write to the trace log.
Replacement values for the variables in the parameter. This can be a single value or an array of values. Numbers are converted automatically to strings.

member.summary: Gets the full path to the local temporary folder the module using.

remarks.para: Use this path if your custom code needs to create a temporary file. The path is provided with a trailing backslash to simplify string manipulations.
If you create temporary files, you are responsible for deleting them before your custom code completes.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IModuleStartInfo.ReadUserPreferences
member.summary: Retrieves user preferences.

remarks.para: User preferences are custom module settings specific to an individual user. They are not specific to a batch or a CaptureFlow process. That means that a user preference stored during task processing for one batch can be retrieved during task processing for a different batch. Preferences are stored by the workflow server, so they are available to the same user regardless of which workstation is used to process tasks.
To create a user preference, do the following:

item.description: Call ReadUserPreferences to retrieve a value accessor object.
Write the setting name and value to the accessor object using one of its write methods.

Call
to store the preferences.

remarks.note: Preferences are stored for the user who logs onto the module. Credentials used to log onto the module are not necessarily the same as the credentials used to log onto the workstation operating system.

member.returns: An object that can be used to access user preferences.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code sets the variable "userID" to the value of the user preference named "EmployeeNumber":
example.code:
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext)
Dim page As IBatchNode Dim prefs As IValueAccessor Dim userID As String
page = task.BatchNode prefs = page.StepData.ReadUserPreferences() userID = prefs.ReadString("EmployeeNumber")
task.CompleteTask()
End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IModuleStartInfo.SaveUserPreferences(Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IValueAccessor)
member.summary: Saves user preferences.

remarks.para: User preferences are custom module settings specific to an individual user. They are not specific to a batch or a CaptureFlow process. That means that a user preference stored during task processing for one batch can be retrieved during task processing for a different batch. Preferences are stored by the workflow server, so they are available to the same user regardless of which workstation is used to process tasks.
To create a user preference, do the following:

item.description:
Call
to retrieve a value accessor object.
Write the setting name and value to the accessor object using one of its write methods.
Call SaveUserPreferences to store the preferences.

remarks.note: Preferences are stored for the user who logs onto the module. Credentials used to log onto the module are not necessarily the same as the credentials used to log onto the workstation operating system.

member.param:
A value accessor object that was retrieved with the
method.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code saves a user preference named "EmployeeNumber", and sets it to the value "123":
example.code:
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext)
Dim page As IBatchNode Dim prefs As IValueAccessor
page = task.BatchNode prefs = page.StepData.ReadUserPreferences() prefs.WriteString("EmployeeNumber", "123") page.StepData.SaveUserPreferences(prefs)
task.CompleteTask()
End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.INodeData.ValueSet
member.summary: Gets an object that can be used to read and write node values.

remarks.para:
A batch node is always accessed in the context of a specific batch step. This property enables you to access node values for the context step. To retrieve node values for other steps, use the
method to change the context of the node.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code sets the task root node's "IndexPlus.TreeNodeModified" value equal to its "ScanPlus.TreeNodeModified" value.
example.code:
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext)
Dim page As IBatchNode Dim pageScan As IBatchNode Dim pageIndex As IBatchNode Dim modified As Integer
page = task.BatchNode
' GET SCANPLUS MODIFIED FLAG pageScan = batchContext.GetStepNode(page, "ScanPlus") modified = pageScan.NodeData.ValueSet.ReadInt("TreeNodeModified")
' SET INDEXPLUS MODIFIED FLAG pageIndex = batchContext.GetStepNode(page, "IndexPlus") pageIndex.NodeData.ValueSet.WriteInt("TreeNodeModified", modified)
task.CompleteTask()
End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IStepDefinitionData.GetValueDefinitionSet
member.summary: Returns an array of all value definitions defined for the workflow step.

remarks.para: This method provides access to the definition information for the values, not the value data itself. For example, you can use it determine a value's data type, or whether it is an input value.
Values are typically defined in a Module Definition File (MDF). You cannot modify value definitions through the GetValueDefinitionSet method.

member.returns: An array of value definitions.

member.summary: Determines whether the value at a specified index is the same as another value.

member.summary: Converts the input text by replacing variable tokens.

In case of error for a format token, this default value is substituted.
Optional parameter. If it is empty, current machine's installed culture is used. Culture is used for month names and default short date format and decimal separator.
Optional. If the format text does not specify format specifier, and this value is not empty, then this is used to format date values.
Optional. If the format text does not specify format specifier, and this value is not empty, then this is used to format numbers.
member.returns: String with substitutions.

member.summary: Interface ITreeNodeAccessor is an accessor object to read the node structure and node values of a hierarchical balanced tree. The leaf nodes are at level 0 and the level increases as you navigate to the root. The node values are accessed through value names. The node is represented by an integer node id value.

Browse level. If lower then descendants are returned. if higher then ancestors are returned.
member.returns: Array of node id values. If level is higher then, a single ancestor node is returned. If level same then reference node is returned. If level is lower, zero or more descendant nodes are returned.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind
member.summary: Enumeration for node structure changes. A node structure change occurs in the context of a reference node. It uses a child node id and an optional anchor node id.

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.None
member.summary: No change

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.NewChild
member.summary: Add new child to reference node. Child - none. Anchor - none. Result - new node id created.

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.DeleteChild
member.summary: Delete existing child from reference node. Child - child node id. Anchor - none. Result - deleted child node id.

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.MoveAsChildNode
member.summary: Move the given node as a child to this node. Place it to the left of anchor node. If anchor node is 0, then place it at end. Child - node to move. Could be parented by some other node or this node. Must have appropriate level. Anchor - Anchor child node. New position is to left of this anchor. If anchor is 0 then new position is the last position. Result - Moved child id.

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.SplitAtChild
member.summary: Split the node at given child node's left edge. A new right sibling node is created and the given child node and all nodes to the right of it are disconnected from parent and appended to the newly created sibling node. Child - node at which the split occurs along left edge. Anchor - none. result - new right sibling node id.

member.name: F:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.NodeStructureChangeKind.MergeChildWithLeftSibling
member.summary: Merge child node with left sibling. Children of the child node are appended to its left sibling and the child node is dropped. If left sibling does not exist, no change occurs. Child - child node which is merged with its left sibling. Anchor - none. Result - merged child id.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.INodeEntryInfo
member.summary: Batch Node entry info. A node entry may imply delete operation if the parent node id is -1. If a node is deleted, the node id must never be re-generated for same Batch handle.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.INodeEntryInfo.NodeId
member.summary: Node id. Must be non zero positive int. While generating node id values the following is recommended. 1. Start with 1 or higher. 2. For each new node added, increment the id vlaue and use it. 3. If a node is deleted, do not reuse the node id. instead always get a new number. A deleted node id must never be used again for the same BatchHandle. Setting values against a deleted node id is fine but it must not be passed in as a valid node id later. An error is thrown at run time if this happens.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.INodeEntryInfo.ParentId
member.summary: Parent node Id. 0 means root node. -1 means delete the node or unlink from parent.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.LocaleChangeAction
member.summary:
Actions that the method
can take when changing the locale of a document.

summary.para: Change the locale and then recreate the value for each field by reparsing that field text using the new locale. If the field text is invalid for the data type, such as when a numeric field has the text "ABC", the field value is replaced by the default value for the data type. If the field text is valid, the newly-parsed value is reformatted according to the field configuration and the text is replaced with the reformatted value.
If the field text before the locale change is empty, the field is not changed. The field text remains blank and the field value remains the default value.

Change the locale and then recreate the text for each field by reformatting that field's value using the specified locale. If the field text is invalid for the data type, such as when a numeric field has the text "ABC", the field text is replaced by the formatted default value for the data type.
If the field text before the locale change is empty, the field is not changed. The field text remains blank and the field value remains the default value.
Change the locale without updating either the text or value for any field in the document.
Change the locale and then process each field as follows.

If the field value has never been changed from the OCR value and the OCR text is not empty, the text is first parsed and if the parse succeeds, the parsed value is reformatted according to the field configuration.
If the field value has been changed from the OCR value and the OCR text is not empty, the value is reformatted according to the field configuration.
If the field text before the locale change is empty, the field is not changed. The field text remains blank and the field value remains the default value.

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.DocumentEventKind
member.summary: Document script event kinds.

remarks.para: The execution order for non-UI tasks is as follows.

item.description: DocumentExtracted
ExecuteValidationRule, once for each validation rule
DocumentUnload

remarks.para: When a data entry form is launched the runtime generates both document data events and form UI control events. The execution order for UI tasks is as follows.

item.description: DocumentLoad
ExecuteValidationRule, once for each validation rule after DocumentLoad and when any field used by the rule has changed
FormLoad
Enter, Exit, ButtonClick, SelectionChange, and ConfirmControl as UI flow causes these events
DocumentUnload

remarks.para: This enumeration is not used in CaptureFlow scripting or by the .NET Code module.

member.summary: Represents a batch node.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData.GetDocuments
member.summary: Gets the documents that belong to this node and its children.
member.remarks:
The contents of the returned array depend on the level of this node as follows.
If this node is a page, the document list is empty.
If this node is a document, the list contains the document as its only entry.
If this node is a folder or higher, the list contains all documents under that node in the order they appear in the batch.
member.returns: Array of document data objects.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData.Level
member.summary: Gets the level this node represents (0 = page, 1 = document, etc.).

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData.NodeId
member.summary: Gets the ID of this node.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData.BatchId
member.summary: Gets the ID of this batch.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData.TaskValues
member.summary: Gets the task-level values dictionary for custom, external data handling.
member.remarks:
Until the task is closed, the script controls the contents of this dictionary and can add, change, or remove values. When the task is closed, any items in the dictionary will be sent to the platform for updating, the details of which are platform-specific. As the dictionary is not supported by all platforms, it may be null and applications must test for this before trying to set values.
For the InputAccel platform, these values are written as dynamic InputAccel nodal values of the task node. For example, if the task is at level 2 (folder) and the script created a TaskValues key "TotalCount" with the value "100", then on exit a dynamic value with name "TotalCount" and string value "100" is created at level 2. InputAccel can only create strings as dynamic values. If the task value is not a string, the value is converted to a string and the format is not deterministic. Therefore, script authors should provide appropriately-formatted strings for all values. Dynamic values are not created for entries with null values.
For platforms other than InputAccel, any data type supported by the platform may be used to pass values. The value name must follow platform-specific name syntax.

remarks.para: If the control was configured as hidden at design time, this method does nothing.
If a databound control is hidden and data entry is incomplete for the control, the operator will not be able to complete the data entry and will not know which field requires completion.

member.param: If true, show control. If false, hide control.

member.summary: Enables or disables the UI control.

If a databound control is disabled and data entry is incomplete for the control, operator will not be able to complete the data entry.

member.param: If true, enable control for input. If false, disable control.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFormControlContext.SetControlReadOnly(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets or clears the read-only state for a text box control.
member.param: True to make the field read-only, false to make it read-write.

remarks.para: This method does nothing when any of the following are true.

item.description: The field was configured as read-only at design time.
The form section containing this control does not allow editing ( is false).
The control is not a text box. Controls other than text boxes do not distunguish between the read-only and enabled states.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFormControlContext.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the text for the control.

remarks.para: For choice-based controls, list boxes and drop-down list boxes, this selects the item that has the same display text as the specified string. For checkboxes, this checks the checkbox if text is "true".

When the text is set in a bound control with a restriction mask, the text is parsed according to the mask and the field value is updated with the parsed text. For example, if the mask is "000-000-0000" and the supplied text will be "800.555.1212", then the field value is "8005551212" and the control text will be "800-555-1212".

When the text is set in a bound control, the text is parsed and the field value is updated. If the value does not parse correctly, such as setting the text to "abc" for a control that is bound to a number field, the specified value is still displayed in the control, but the data field is set to its default value.

member.param: Text value to set.

member.returns: Current choice names or an empty list if the control is not a list box or drop-down list box.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.UnmarkFieldForValidationRule(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Unmarks a dependent field so that the rule validation error is not shown for the unmarked field.

remarks.para: The specified field is only unmarked for the specified validation rule, not for other rules that depend on the field. A dependent field may be unmarked but cannot be marked again.

This method should be called during the DocumentLoad event to prevent the field from being marked with rule the validation error. Unmarking a dependent field after the validation rule has run will not clear any existing validation error. In this case, you must execute the rule again or explicitly clear the error.
If the rule does not contain as a dependent field, the method does nothing and no error is returned.
This method is not supported in the .NET Code module.

member.param: The case-insensitive rule name.
The case-insensitive field name.

member.param: The case-insensitive query name.
A dictionary of named parameters to substitute in the query statement.
The expected number of returned rows
member.returns: true if row count expectation is met, else false

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.StepCustomValue
member.summary: Gets the custom input string value configured as part of the step for the current task or an empty string if no value was configured.

remarks.para: All documents in the task share the same value.
This property is not supported in the .NET Code module.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.TempDirectoryPath
member.summary: Gets the path to a directory the script can use to store temporary files.

remarks.para: The directory is automatically purged by the calling framework, although script-created temporary files are guaranteed to exist until end of current task. This directory is shared by more than just the current task, so script authors should always use global unique identifiers to avoid file name conflicts.
This property is not supported in the .NET Code module.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.TaskValues
member.summary: Gets the task-level output values dictionary for custom, external data handling.

remarks.para: Until the task is closed, the script controls the contents of this dictionary and can add, change, or remove values. When the task is closed, any items in the dictionary will be sent to the platform for updating, the details of which are platform-specific. As the dictionary is not supported by all platforms, it may be null and applications must test for this before trying to set values.

These values are written as dynamic InputAccel nodal values of the task node. For example, if the task is at level 2 (folder) and the script created a TaskValues key "TotalCount" with the value "100", then on exit a dynamic value with name "TotalCount" and string value "100" is created at level 2. InputAccel can only create strings as dynamic values. If the task value is not a string, the value is converted to a string and the format is not deterministic. Therefore, script authors should provide appropriately-formatted strings for all values. Dynamic values are not created for entries with null values.
This property is not supported in the .NET Code module.

member.para: For platforms other than InputAccel, any data type supported by the platform may be used to pass values. The value name must follow platform-specific name syntax.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.CustomValue
member.summary: Gets the custom string value for this object configured as part of the document type or an empty string if no value was configured.

remarks.para: All objects that are associated with document metadata have an optional custom string value that may be configured at design time.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimDataContext.TaskFinishOnErrorNotAllowed
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the operator is prevented from completing the task in Captiva Desktop when the document has errors.

remarks.para: This value is used only by Captiva Desktop. Tasks always complete in Extraction independent of the value of this property.

member.summary: Represents the run-time data for a field.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.SetDataConfirmed(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets or clears the field confirmed status.
member.param: true to confirm the field value, false to clear the confirmation.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.SetValue(System.Object)
member.summary: Sets the data value, updating the text shown in UI.

remarks.para: When the field value is set, the new value is formatted and displayed in the UI. When the method is called during Extraction and Captiva Desktop, the validation rules for the field are also reevaluated. Both of these are true whether or not the new value is different than the current value.
If has a different data type than the field, the value is converted to the field's data type. If the conversion fails, the field value and text are both set to the default for the field's data type.

member.param: The new field value.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.SetValidationError(System.Exception)
member.summary: Marks or clears the validation error.

remarks.para: Fields with field errors or validation rule failures are marked with validation errors by the system; these errors are cleared once the field value is correct and the rules do not fail. This method provides a mechanism for manually marking or clearing errors outside of the automated mechanism.
If the field has an error and is not null, the new exception replaces the existing error.

member.param: A non-null exception to mark the field in error or null to clear existing field and validation-rule errors.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.FormatValue(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Formats a value using the specified locale and configured field syntax.

remarks.para: This method provides a way for a script to access the formatting capabilities of a field format without any explicit knowledge of the field settings.

If has a different data type than the field, the value is converted to the field's data type. If the converstion fails, the returned text is the default value for the field's data type as a formatted string.

example.para: If the field is a number field that is configured to use 2 decimal places and the value is the number 42, the value returned by this method is "42.00".

member.param: The value to format.
The locale name such as "en-US" to use for formatting the object or null to use the current document locale. Supported locales are those supported by the .NET framework.
member.returns: The formatted text.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.Parse(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Parses a string into an object using the specified locale and configured field syntax.

remarks.para: This method provides a way for a script to access the parsing capabilities of a field format without any explicit knowledge of the field settings.
If parsing fails, an exception is thrown.

example.para: If the field is a number field and the string is "42.20", the value returned by this method is the number 42.2.

member.param: The text to parse.
The locale name such as "en-US" to use for parsing the text or null to use the current document locale. Supported locales are those supported by the .NET framework.
member.returns: The value of the parsed text as an object of the same data type as the field on which this method is called.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.MarkValueChanged
member.summary: Causes the value to be considered "updated," reevaluating the related validation rules.

remarks.para: This method does not change either the field value or text.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimFieldDataContext.HasUnflaggedError(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether this field has an error that is not suppressed by the specified flag on either the field or a related dependent field.

remarks.para: The method returns true if all of the following are true:

item.description: The field has an error.
The field does not contain the specified flag.
If the error is a validation rule error, no other field for the same error contains the specified flag.

remarks.para: When an operator in Captiva Desktop applies a flag to a field that has a validation rule error, the error is suppressed in the UI for both that field containing the flag and all other dependent fields with the same error. In cases where a flag is used to indicate that the error is allowed, the script must determine which errors are allowed and which are not. A script can use this method to determine whether the error on a field has been suppressed by the operator using a specific flag.

member.param: The value of the flag to test.
member.returns: True if the field has an error that is not suppressed by the specified flag.

member.summary: Creates a new annotation and applies it to the image after the script completes.

remarks.para: The foreground and background colors must be formatted as 4 bytes of ARGB with Alpha as the most significant byte and Blue as the least significant byte.
The font used for text annotations is not configurable.

Annotations created with this method are applied to the image in the order they were created. If annotations in the profile are also applied by calling , those annotations are applied before any custom annotations.

The type of the annotation. The value must be one of: "Redaction", "Text", "Highlight", or "Comment". Other types are not supported.

The color used for the background, redactions, and highlights. Refer to Remarks for details on the format.
The opacity of the annotation. The valid range is 0.0-1.0 where 0.0 is transparent and 1.0 is opaque.
The text shown for text annotations and included as a comment for all other annotation types. The text can use placeholders to substitute variables from batch node values.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IValueAccessor.AssignValue(System.String,Emc.InputAccel.CaptureClient.IValueReader,System.String)
member.summary: Assigns value data directly from one value to another value.

remarks.para: The data types of the two values either must be the same, or the system must be able to convert the source data to the destination value's data type.
File value data that is assigned from one value to another does not create a new physical file on disk. Instead, a new reference to the same file is created.

member.param: The name of the destination value to assign the data to.
The value set that contains the source data.
The name of the source value to retrieve the data from.

example.para: The following Visual Basic code assigns the value data from the ScanPlus value named "BatchProcessingTime" to a custom batch value named "ScanProcessingTime":
example.code:
Public Overrides Sub ExecuteTask(ByVal task As IClientTask, ByVal batchContext As IBatchContext)
Dim batchRootScanPlus As IBatchNode Dim batchRootCustomValues As IBatchNode
batchRootScanPlus = batchContext.GetRoot("ScanPlus") batchRootCustomValues = batchContext.GetRoot("CustomValues")
batchRootCustomValues.NodeData.ValueSet.AssignValue("ScanProcessingTime", batchRootScanPlus.NodeData.ValueSet, "BatchProcessingTime")
task.CompleteTask()
End Sub
example.para: Here is the same example in Visual C#:

member.name: T:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.UimLccScript
member.summary: Class UimLccScript is the base class for all UIM scripting modules used to access LCC batch. A LCC scripting module is run when a noop step is configured for scripting. The scripting class must extend this class and have a class name based on the process flow name as "Custom.LccUimScript.Script[process flow name with spaces replaced by underscore]". For every step that is configured for scripting, a method with the following signature is invoked. Execute[step name, with spaces replaced by underscore](ILccBatch batch, string customString, int customInt); Step name is case sensitive.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.UimScriptBatchCreate.PrepareList(Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimScriptBatchCreateListContext)
member.summary: Executes a script whenever a raw list of files is collected from input directory for batch creation. This event is called after the service scans a directory and prepares BatchFileList and SkippedFileList. ErrorFileList is kept emtpy.

remarks.para: The batch creation module compiles a raw list and from the raw list extracts files that may be used to create a batch. It also prepares a list of files that will be skipped. The profile configuration defines how to skip files and how to order the files. The script implementation may make the following modifications. 1. Change the order in BatchFileList. 2. Remove entries from BatchFileList. This means that the files will be seen in next scan. 3. Move entries between BatchFileList and SkippedFileList. 4. Remove entries from SkippedfileList. This means these files will be seen in next scan. 5. Delete all entries from BatchFileList. This means that batch creation step will be skipped. We need atleast one file to create a batch. 6. Add new files to BatchCreateList. The new file must be created using CreateFile() method in listContext object. The service will manage the life time of this file. 6. Delete all entries from BatchFileList and SkippedFileList. Then recreate these lists from files from RawfileList. This means that the configuration is bypassed in preparing the lists.

It is important that any new file added is created using CreateFile() api. New files are added when multipage files are parsed and split into separate files or files are duplicated for business reason or files are converted to different format.

BatchFileList is an ordered file list and exactly one batch is created per list if the list is non empty. Script may introduce page breaks and folder breaks and L3 breaks by using these special file paths: *PageBreak*, *FolderBreak*,*Level3Break*

member.param: The list that will be used to create a batch.

member.summary: This routine is called before a batch is created.
member.param: The list used to create batch nodes, values and create info
Batch info. Script may modify the Batch name schema or provide a literal batch name.
Batch nodes. Script may edit and add new nodes, delete nodes or change parenting. If the node list is cleared then no batch is created.
Values. Script may modify the values.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.UimScriptMainCore.NodeMoved(Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData,Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData,System.Int32,Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.IUimNodeData,System.Int32,Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.GlobalEventReason)
member.summary: Called when a node is moved in the task tree.

remarks.para: If the node has been repositioned within the same parent, and are the same. The method is only called for nodes that are explicitly moved; it is not executed for other affected nodes. For example, if the third of three pages in a document is moved to the front of the document, the event is executed only for that page.

When a node is split, the new node is first created for which
is called. Each affected child node is then moved to its new parent with NodeMoved called for each.

When two nodes are merged, each affected child node is moved to its new parent with NodeMoved called for each. The old parent node is then deleted for which
is called.

member.param: The node that was moved.
The new parent of the moved node.
The new position of the node in its parent.
The previous parent of the moved node, which will be the same as for nodes moved to a different location in the same parent.
The old position of the node in its previous parent.
The reason the node was moved.

called for each.

The reason the node was added.

member.name: M:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.UimScriptMainCore.BeforeDocumentExtracted(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Object})
member.summary: Called before data is extracted from a document.

remarks.para: This event is fired once for each document before Extraction processes any of the pages in that document. A script author can use it to initialize state used during the extraction process, such as scripts executed as part of the freeform rules.

The dictionary is populated with document-level IA values that are defined on the Extraction step. For each IA value with the naming pattern "PreUimData_<ValueName>", contains an entry called "<ValueName>". For example, if the Extraction step contains the dynamic value "PreUimData_First" with a value of "test" and "PreUimData_Second" with a value of 4, then will contain two entries: "First" = "test" and "Second" = 4.
As the dictionary is discarded after the event has completed, any modification to its contents will be lost.

member.param: Dictionary of document level IA values.

member.name: P:Emc.InputAccel.UimScript.UimScriptMainCore.IALoginUserName
member.summary: Gets the domain and user name used to login to the Captiva Capture server.

remarks.para: If the returned value is "*", the connection to the server is made with the user under which the application is running as defined by the system property.
